   120-130s. He was bolused with 450 mg of IV amiodarone in the ER and was
   on a gtt. He is currently DNR/DNI after undergoing a successful VT
   ablation for which his code status was changed to full code.  Code
   status reversed after procedure.  Was stable until he developed VT
   overnight on [**9-23**].  Was repaced into sinus rhythm and transferred back
   to CCU.  Again went into VT.  VT detect re-set to 115 from 140.
   Patient received multiple shocks and has been in sinus rhythm since
   2AM.  Lidocaine and amiodarone gtt started but patient became agitated
   and lost IV access.  Lidocaine had not worked well in the past for
   patient.
   - Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] repeated ablation on [**2147-9-25**]. Currently pt is paced and
   in sinus However, Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] may want to take pt for LV lead
   replacement since the lead is not capturing. Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] expressed
   pts VT might be originating from that site.
   -Currently on PO amiodarone- will continue PO and not the drip.
   - Lidocaine not working in past- will not restart at this time. Might
   also be contributing to his altered mental status.
   - Keep ICD on
   - receiving repeated ICD shocks, and transitioning to comfort care.
   Due to  his multiple shocks ICD may need battery replacement.  Discuss
   with family how they would like to proceed.
   - extensive conversation with daughter (HCP) took place, where decision
   was made to keep ICD on, and instruction was provided that the three
   modalities of therapy for this irregular rhythm are
   medication/ICD/ablation (all of which he has had and extensively
   pursued).
   Post-cath check at 0650hrs
   -Femoral sheath removed at 23:30, Left one femoral venous access intact
   since patient is getting propofol through peripheral and dopamine
   through femoral.  Will need to remove femoral access once dopamine is
   completely weaned off this AM
   -Rt lower extremity to bruits, indurations, or active bleeding over
   site. No mottling of the skin or toes. DP/PT 2+
   Respiratory --  Pt was intubated for the ablation.
   -Unable to extubate as originally planned at 0400hrs since pt was
   unable to be weened off the dopamine.  Most likely secondary to the
   hypotensive effect of propofol.
   -Respiratory chanced his ventilator setting to Pressure support with
   plans to extubate later this morning.
   .
   #. Pump - No signs of CHF at this time. Pt with known chronic systolic
   heart failure with EF of 20%. We will continue his home medications:
   statin, ASA, and metoprolol.
   -No signs of decompensation at the moment.  Monitor UOP since pt
   received a lot of fluids during his ablation.
   .
   #. CAD - Pt with known CAD s/p CABG. Chest pain free, other than his VT
   and shocks.  ASA, statin, BB were continued as above.  ACEI held as
   above, due to hypotension. Enzymes suggest mild cardiac injury after
   shock, but most likely he is not having ACS.
   .
   #. OA - pain was well controlled on Tylenol.  Will d/c opiates today
   secondary to altered mental status.
   .
   #. Anxiety - Discontinued ativan home-dose. Consider low dose mood
   stabilizer at night, if agitation continues.
   -Received Olanzapine sublingual 2.5mg  with good response.
   -Pt altered mental status and anxiety seem to be improving.  Currently
   on propofol while intubated.
   - If agitated, consider zydis again vs. haldol 1 mg
   FEN:
   -Pt was hypokalemic yesterday to 2.2 was repleated with 40mEq IV and
   2gm of Mg.  This morning
s potassium was 3.7 repleated 20mEq this AM.
   -Follow lytes
   .
   #. Code - patient is DNR/DNI.  Not to be externally shocked. Leave ICD

Summary:

The patient, an 86-year-old Russian-speaking man with a history of CAD, MI, and CABG, was admitted to the ICU for recurrent VTach and ICD firing. He underwent a VT ablation procedure and was initially stable, but later developed VT again and received multiple shocks. He was paced and in sinus rhythm, but his ICD battery needs replacement. The patient is DNR/DNI and has a code status of no external shocks.

Potential medical complications:

1. Ventricular Tachycardia (VTach): The patient has a history of VTach and has received multiple shocks. He may continue to experience VTach episodes, which can lead to cardiac arrest and death.
2. ICD battery replacement: The patient's ICD battery needs replacement, which may require additional procedures and may increase the risk of complications.
3. Chronic Systolic Heart Failure (CHF): The patient has chronic systolic CHF with an EF of 20%, which may lead to decompensation and further complications.
4. Hypokalemia: The patient was hypokalemic yesterday and received potassium replacement. He may continue to experience hypokalemia, which can lead to cardiac arrhythmias and other complications.
5. Altered Mental Status: The patient has altered mental status and is receiving propofol sedation. He may continue to experience altered mental status, which can lead to respiratory depression and other complications.
6. DVT: The patient is at risk for DVT due to his immobility and may require anticoagulation therapy.
7. Pneumonia: The patient is at risk for pneumonia due to his intubation and may require antibiotic therapy.
8. Cardiac Arrest: The patient is at risk for cardiac arrest due to his VTach and CHF.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 86-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction, and cardiac ablation. He was recently discharged from the CCU with an ICD firing, and now returns with recurrent ventricular tachycardia (VT) on PO amiodarone.

The patient underwent a successful VT ablation procedure, but developed VT overnight on [**9-23**]. He received multiple shocks and was in sinus rhythm since 2AM. The patient is currently paced and in sinus rhythm, but may need LV lead replacement since the lead is not capturing.

The patient has been intubated for the ablation and is currently receiving propofol and dopamine. He is unable to be extubated as originally planned due to the hypotensive effect of propofol.

The patient's medical conditions include:

1. Chronic systolic heart failure with EF of 20%.
2. Chronic atrial fibrillation with ventricular pacing.
3. Recurrent ventricular tachycardia.
4. Chronic kidney disease.
5. Hypokalemia.
6. Altered mental status.
7. Anxiety.
8. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

The patient's medications include:

1. PO amiodarone.
2. Lidocaine.
3. Propofol.
4. Dopamine.
5. Statin.
6. ASA.
7. Metoprolol.
8. Olanzapine.

The patient's laboratory results include:

1. Potassium: 2.5, 3.2, 3.7.
2. Creatinine: 1.1, 1.0, 0.8.
3. Hemoglobin: 11.1 g/dL, 9.6 g/dL, 7.5 g/dL.
4. Platelet count: 172 K/uL, 140 K/uL, 101 K/uL.
5. White blood cell count: 11.5, 9.6, 7.5.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Ventricular tachycardia.
2. Cardiac arrest.
3. Heart failure.
4. Chronic kidney disease.
5. Hypokalemia.
6. Altered mental status.
7. Anxiety.
8. Respiratory failure.
9. Sepsis.

The patient's plan includes:

1. Continue PO amiodarone.
2. Monitor for signs of VT.
3. Wean dopamine and extubate patient.
4. Consider LV lead replacement.
5. Monitor for signs of heart failure.
6. Monitor for signs of chronic kidney disease.
7. Monitor for signs of hypokalemia.
8. Monitor for signs of altered mental status.
9. Monitor for signs of anxiety.
10. Consider low-dose mood stabilizer at night if agitation continues.

The patient's family has been informed of his condition and has made decisions regarding his care.

Based on the provided progress note, here is a summary of the patient's current condition and potential medical complications:

**Current Condition:**

* The patient is a 86-year-old male with a history of CAD, s/p MI and CABG, chronic AFib with V-pacing, and chronic systolic CHF with EF 20%.
* He underwent VT ablation procedure yesterday and was in sinus rhythm initially, but converted back to VT and was shocked several times.
* The patient is currently intubated and receiving propofol and dopamine through a femoral venous access.
* His code status is DNR/DNI, and he is not to be externally shocked.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Cardiac Complications:**
	* Recurrence of VT or VF
	* ICD battery replacement due to multiple shocks
	* Potential for LV lead replacement due to non-capturing lead
2. **Respiratory Complications:**
	* Pneumonia or ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to prolonged intubation
	* Difficulty weaning off ventilator support
3. **Gastrointestinal Complications:**
	* Stress ulcer or bleeding due to prolonged use of corticosteroids and anticoagulation therapy
	* Constipation or bowel obstruction due to prolonged immobility
4. **Neurological Complications:**
	* Altered mental status or delirium due to sedation, hypotension, or electrolyte imbalances
	* Potential for seizures due to electrolyte imbalances or medication interactions
5. **Infection Complications:**
	* Catheter-related bloodstream infection (CRBSI) due to prolonged use of central lines
	* Urinary tract infection (UTI) due to indwelling urinary catheter
6. **Hematological Complications:**
	* Hemorrhage or bleeding due to prolonged use of anticoagulation therapy
	* Thrombocytopenia or bleeding due to platelet dysfunction or medication interactions

**Plan:**

* Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and adjust therapy as needed
* Wean the patient off propofol and dopamine as tolerated
* Consider LV lead replacement if the lead is not capturing
* Monitor for signs of respiratory, gastrointestinal, neurological, and hematological complications
* Discuss goals of care with the patient's daughter and family members
* Provide education on the patient's condition and treatment plan to the family members.

Summary:

The patient is an 86-year-old Russian-speaking man with a history of coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction, and coronary artery bypass grafting. He has chronic atrial fibrillation with ventricular pacing, chronic systolic heart failure with an ejection fraction of 20%, and has recently undergone a ventricular tachycardia (VT) ablation procedure. The patient presented to the emergency department with recurrent VT and was subsequently transferred to the intensive care unit (ICU).

The patient's current vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 60 beats per minute, blood pressure of 96/50 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 94%. He is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. His laboratory results show mild cardiac injury after shock, but his enzymes suggest that he is not having an acute coronary syndrome.

The patient's medications include amiodarone, lidocaine, verapamil, and diltiazem, which have been started or continued to manage his VT and other cardiac arrhythmias. His code status is full code, but his family has also discussed the possibility of changing the generator in his implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) at some point.

Potential medical complications:

1. Ventricular tachycardia: The patient's history of VT and recent ablation procedure make it essential to monitor his rhythm and adjust his medications as needed to prevent further episodes.
2. Heart failure: The patient's chronic systolic heart failure with an ejection fraction of 20% increases his risk of decompensation, particularly if he develops a cardiac arrhythmia or experiences fluid overload.
3. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and ventricular pacing increases his risk of developing other cardiac arrhythmias, such as atrial flutter or ventricular fibrillation.
4. Infection: The patient's recent hospitalization and use of central lines and other invasive devices increase his risk of developing an infection, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) or central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI).
5. Delirium: The patient's altered mental status and use of sedatives and analgesics increase his risk of developing delirium, which can worsen his cognitive function and increase his risk of falls and other complications.
6. Hypokalemia: The patient's hypokalemia and use of diuretics increase his risk of developing further electrolyte imbalances, particularly hypokalemia, which can lead to cardiac arrhythmias and other complications.
7. Pulmonary embolism: The patient's history of cardiac arrhythmias and use of anticoagulation therapy increase his risk of developing a pulmonary embolism, particularly if he develops deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary hypertension.

   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known firstname 20**] [**Known lastname **] is a 86 yo Russian speaking man with h/o CAD s/p MI and
   CABG in [**2136**], chronic AFib with V-pacing, chronic systolic CHF with EF
   20%, recently discharged from CCU with ICD firing, now returns with
   recurrent VT on PO amiodarone, now s/p VT ablation procedure x 2.
   .
   #. Rhythm - Pt with known VTach and s/p ICD firing, presented due to
   ICD firing and chest pain. Patient has stable VS and was in VT at
   120-130s. He was bolused with 450 mg of IV amiodarone in the ER and was
   on a gtt. He is currently DNR/DNI after undergoing a successful VT
   ablation for which his code status was changed to full code.  Code
   status reversed after procedure.  Was stable until he developed VT
   overnight on [**9-23**].  Was repaced into sinus rhythm and transferred back
   to CCU.  Again went into VT.  VT detect re-set to 115 from 140.
   Patient received multiple shocks and has been in sinus rhythm since
   2AM.  Lidocaine and amiodarone gtt started but patient became agitated
   and lost IV access.  Lidocaine had not worked well in the past for
   patient.
   - LV pacing at 60 currently.
   - RV pacing off.
   - now s/p ablation x 2 (most recently [**2147-9-25**])
   - Currently pt is paced and in sinus; intrinsic conduction.
   - Keep ICD on
   - family wants generator changed at some point
   - Lidocaine not working in past- will not restart at this time. Might
   also be contributing to his altered mental status.
   - Due to  his multiple shocks ICD will need battery replacement.
   Discuss with family how they would like to proceed.
   - extensive conversation with daughter (HCP) took place, where decision
   was made to keep ICD on, and instruction was provided that the three
   modalities of therapy for this irregular rhythm are
   medication/ICD/ablation (all of which he has had and extensively
   pursued).
   - D/C amiodarone and started verapamil yesterday.
   - Add diltiazem IV if goes into Vtach
   .
   # Respiratory
 extubated, off sedation, off pressors.
   #. Pump - No signs of CHF at this time. Pt with known chronic systolic
   heart failure with EF of 20%. We will continue his home medications:
   statin, ASA, and metoprolol.
   -No signs of decompensation at the moment.  Monitor UOP since pt
   received a lot of fluids during his ablation.
   .
   #. CAD - Pt with known CAD s/p CABG. Chest pain free, other than his VT
   and shocks.  ASA, statin, BB were continued as above.  ACEI held as
   above, due to hypotension. Enzymes suggest mild cardiac injury after
   shock, but most likely he is not having ACS.
   .
   #. OA - pain was well controlled on Tylenol.  Will d/c opiates today
   secondary to altered mental status.
   .
   #. Anxiety - Discontinued ativan home-dose. Consider low dose mood
   stabilizer at night, if agitation continues.
   -Received Olanzapine sublingual 2.5mg with good response two nights ago
   -Pt altered mental status and anxiety seem to be improving.  Currently
   on propofol while intubated.
   - If agitated, consider zydis again vs. haldol 1 mg
   FEN:
   -Pt was hypokalemic yesterday to 2.2 was repleated with 40mEq IV and
   2gm of Mg.  This morning
s potassium was 3.2, being repleted.
   -Follow lytes
   .
   #. Code - patient is DNR/DNI.  Not to be externally shocked. Leave ICD
   on
   .
   #. Prophy
 DVT: heparin SQ; No need for PPI; Colace/Senna.
   .
   #. Contact - Next of [**Doctor First Name **]: [**Last Name (LF) **],[**First Name3 (LF) **], Relationship: DAUGHTER, Phone:
   [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9232**] (home) and [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9287**] (cell).

   Stress ulcer:

   Code status: Full code
   Disposition: CCU for now

Based on the progress note, here is a summary of the patient's condition and potential medical complications:

**Current Condition:**

* The patient is an 86-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction, and chronic atrial fibrillation with ventricular pacing.
* He has chronic systolic heart failure with an ejection fraction of 20%.
* He has undergone two VT ablation procedures and has been experiencing recurrent VT.
* He is currently paced at 60 beats per minute and is in sinus rhythm.
* He has been extubated and is off sedation and pressors.
* He has been experiencing altered mental status, which is attributed to his medication regimen and recent shocks.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Cardiac Complications:**
	* Recurrence of VT or ventricular fibrillation
	* Cardiac arrhythmias due to the patient's underlying conditions
	* Cardiac decompensation due to heart failure
2. **Respiratory Complications:**
	* Respiratory failure due to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) or other underlying respiratory conditions
	* Pneumonia or ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)
3. **Neurological Complications:**
	* Altered mental status due to medication or other underlying conditions
	* Seizures or status epilepticus
4. **Gastrointestinal Complications:**
	* Gastrointestinal bleeding due to anticoagulation therapy
	* Nausea and vomiting due to medication or other underlying conditions
5. **Infectious Complications:**
	* Bacteremia or sepsis due to IV catheters or other invasive devices
	* Urinary tract infections (UTIs) or other infections due to urinary catheterization
6. **Other Complications:**
	* Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary embolism (PE) due to immobility or other factors
	* Renal failure or acute kidney injury due to fluid overload or other factors

**Recommendations:**

1. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and adjust his medication regimen as necessary.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his oxygen therapy as necessary.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust his medication regimen as necessary.
4. Monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status and adjust his medication regimen as necessary.
5. Monitor the patient's infectious status and adjust his antibiotic therapy as necessary.
6. Consider placing the patient on prophylactic anticoagulation therapy to prevent DVT or PE.
7. Consider placing the patient on prophylactic antibiotics to prevent UTIs or other infections.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust his fluid management as necessary.

   .

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 86-year-old Russian-speaking man with a history of coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction, and coronary artery bypass grafting, who has undergone a ventricular tachycardia (VT) ablation procedure twice.

The patient has been experiencing recurrent VT, which has been treated with amiodarone and lidocaine, but has not responded well to these medications. He has been paced at 60 beats per minute and has been in sinus rhythm since 2 AM.

The patient has a history of chronic systolic heart failure with an ejection fraction of 20% and has been experiencing mild cardiac injury after shock, but it is likely that he is not having an acute coronary syndrome.

The patient has also been experiencing leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 14.2, which may be related to an infection, and has been started on Flagyl for possible Clostridium difficile (C. diff) colitis.

The patient's medication regimen includes statin, aspirin, metoprolol, and verapamil, and he is being monitored for signs of decompensation.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of VT and recurrent episodes of VT may increase his risk of developing other cardiac arrhythmias, such as atrial fibrillation or ventricular fibrillation.
2. Infection: The patient's leukocytosis and possible C. diff infection may increase his risk of developing other infections, such as pneumonia or urinary tract infections.
3. Heart failure: The patient's history of chronic systolic heart failure and mild cardiac injury after shock may increase his risk of developing heart failure.
4. Electrolyte imbalances: The patient's hypokalemia and potential electrolyte imbalances may increase his risk of developing cardiac arrhythmias or other complications.
5. Medication side effects: The patient's medication regimen, including amiodarone and lidocaine, may cause side effects such as nausea, vomiting, or altered mental status.

It is essential to monitor the patient's condition closely and adjust his medication regimen and treatment plan as needed to prevent these complications and ensure his optimal care.

   Mr. [**Known firstname 20**] [**Known lastname **] is a 86 yo Russian speaking man with h/o CAD s/p MI and
   CABG in [**2136**], chronic AFib with V-pacing, chronic systolic CHF with EF
   20%, recently discharged from CCU with ICD firing, now returns with
   recurrent VT on PO amiodarone, now s/p VT ablation procedure x 2.
   .
   #. Rhythm - Pt with known VTach and s/p ICD firing, presented due to
   ICD firing and chest pain. Patient has stable VS and was in VT at
   120-130s. He was bolused with 450 mg of IV amiodarone in the ER and was
   on a gtt. He is currently DNR/DNI after undergoing a successful VT
   ablation for which his code status was changed to full code.  Code
   status reversed after procedure.  Was stable until he developed VT
   overnight on [**9-23**].  Was repaced into sinus rhythm and transferred back
   to CCU.  Again went into VT.  VT detect re-set to 115 from 140.
   Patient received multiple shocks and has been in sinus rhythm since
   2AM.  Lidocaine and amiodarone gtt were started but patient became
   agitated and lost IV access.  Lidocaine had not worked well in the past
   for patient.
   - LV pacing at 60 currently
   - RV pacing off.
   - now s/p ablation x 2 (most recently [**2147-9-25**])
   - Currently pt is paced and in sinus; intrinsic conduction.
   - Keep ICD on
   - family wants generator changed at some point
   - D/C amiodarone and started verapamil yesterday.
   - Add diltiazem IV if goes into Vtach
   .
   # Respiratory
 extubated, off sedation, off pressors.
   .
   #. Pump - No signs of CHF at this time. Pt with known chronic systolic
   heart failure with EF of 20%. We will continue his home medications:
   statin, ASA, and metoprolol.
   -No signs of decompensation at the moment.  Monitor UOP since pt
   received a lot of fluids during his ablation.
   .
   # Leukocytosis- WBC up to 14.2 this AM (~9 yesterday).  Increased stool
   overnight and abdominal tenderness to exam this morning.  Possible
   C.diff
   - Stool sent for C.diff toxin
   - Patient started on Flagyl 500mg PO TID
   .
   #. CAD - Pt with known CAD s/p CABG. Chest pain free, other than his VT
   and shocks.  ASA, statin, BB were continued as above.  ACEI held as
   above, due to hypotension. Enzymes suggest mild cardiac injury after
   shock, but most likely he is not having ACS.
   .
   #. OA - pain was well controlled on Tylenol.  No opiates given altered
   mental status history with opioid administration
   .
   #. Anxiety - Discontinued ativan home-dose. Consider low dose mood
   stabilizer at night, if agitation continues.
   -Received Olanzapine sublingual 2.5mg with good response four nights
   ago
   -Pt altered mental status and anxiety seem to be improving.  Currently
   on propofol while intubated.
   - If agitated, consider zydis again vs. haldol 1 mg
   FEN:
   - Hypokalemic to 3.2 this AM.
   - Will replete with 80mEq IV K+.
   - Follow lytes
   .
   #. Code - patient is DNR/DNI.  Not to be externally shocked. Leave ICD
   on
   .
   #. Prophy
 DVT: heparin SQ; No need for PPI; Colace/Senna.

   #. Contact - Next of [**Doctor First Name **]: [**Last Name (LF) **],[**First Name3 (LF) **], Relationship: DAUGHTER, Phone:

Summary:

The patient, an 86-year-old Russian-speaking man, was admitted to the ICU with recurrent ventricular tachycardia (VT) and a history of cardiac arrest. He underwent a VT ablation procedure and was successfully paced back into sinus rhythm. The patient is currently extubated and off sedation, but still requires cardiac monitoring. He is experiencing leukocytosis, increased stool output, and abdominal tenderness, which may be related to Clostridium difficile (C. diff) infection. The patient is also experiencing anxiety and altered mental status, which is being managed with propofol and other medications.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. C. diff infection: The patient's leukocytosis, increased stool output, and abdominal tenderness suggest a possible C. diff infection. If left untreated, this could lead to severe complications, including sepsis and death.
2. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of VT and cardiac arrest, as well as his current use of anti-arrhythmic medications, increase his risk of developing further cardiac arrhythmias.
3. Infection: The patient's immunosuppressed state, combined with his recent hospitalization and medical procedures, increase his risk of developing infections, including pneumonia, urinary tract infections, and sepsis.
4. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's increased stool output and abdominal tenderness may be related to gastrointestinal bleeding, which could lead to hypovolemic shock and other complications.
5. Renal dysfunction: The patient's hypokalemia and potential electrolyte imbalance increase his risk of developing renal dysfunction, which could lead to acute kidney injury and other complications.
6. Respiratory failure: The patient's recent extubation and potential respiratory instability increase his risk of developing respiratory failure, which could lead to ventilator dependence and other complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and adjust his anti-arrhythmic medications as needed.
2. Start empiric treatment for C. diff infection, including antibiotics and stool testing.
3. Monitor the patient's stool output and abdominal tenderness, and consider further evaluation and treatment if these symptoms persist or worsen.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte levels, including potassium, and adjust his medications and fluids as needed to prevent electrolyte imbalance.
5. Consider further evaluation and treatment for the patient's gastrointestinal symptoms, including endoscopy and colonoscopy.
6. Monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his oxygen therapy and other respiratory support as needed.
7. Consider further evaluation and treatment for the patient's anxiety and altered mental status, including psychotherapy and medications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 86-year-old Russian-speaking man with a history of CAD, s/p MI and CABG, chronic AFib with V-pacing, chronic systolic CHF with EF 20%, and recently discharged from CCU with ICD firing. He was readmitted due to recurrent VT on PO amiodarone and underwent a VT ablation procedure.

Current status:

* The patient is extubated and off sedation, with a stable vital sign profile, including a heart rate of 60, blood pressure of 96/50 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 94%.
* He is paced at 60 beats per minute and in sinus rhythm.
* The ICD is still on, and the family wants to discuss replacing the generator at some point.
* The patient has a history of VT and ICD firing, and has received multiple shocks.

Potential medical complications:

* Ventricular tachycardia (VT) and ventricular fibrillation (Vfib) remain a concern due to the patient's history of VT and ICD firing.
* The patient's chronic systolic heart failure with EF 20% may lead to decompensation, especially with fluid overload or decreased cardiac output.
* The patient's history of CAD and recent CABG may increase the risk of cardiac complications, such as myocardial infarction or cardiac arrest.
* The patient's altered mental status and agitation may be related to the use of sedatives, pain medications, or electrolyte imbalances, and may increase the risk of falls or other complications.
* The patient's DNR/DNI status and the decision to keep the ICD on may lead to conflicts or disagreements with family members or healthcare providers.

Assessment and plan:

* The patient will continue to be monitored for VT and Vfib, and the ICD will remain on.
* The patient's cardiac medications, including statin, ASA, and metoprolol, will be continued.
* The patient's pain will be managed with Tylenol, and the use of opioids will be discontinued due to altered mental status.
* The patient's anxiety will be managed with low-dose mood stabilizers, and the use of sedatives will be discontinued.
* The patient's electrolytes will be monitored, and potassium repletion will be continued as needed.
* The patient's DVT prophylaxis will be continued with heparin SQ.
* The patient's family will be educated on the patient's condition, treatment plan, and code status, and will be involved in decision-making regarding the patient's care.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient, an 86-year-old Russian-speaking man with a history of coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction, and cardiac ablation, is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) due to recurrent ventricular tachycardia (VT).

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.4°C, heart rate of 60 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 96/50 mmHg. His respiratory support includes a ventilator in CPAP/PSV mode, with a tidal volume of 460 mL and a peak inspiratory pressure of 11 cmH2O.

The patient's physical examination is notable for a pacemaker rhythm, with a regular rate and normal S1 and S2 sounds. His lungs are clear, and his abdomen is soft with mild tenderness in the left lower quadrant.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 11.5 K/uL, hemoglobin of 12.2 g/dL, and platelet count of 199 K/uL. His electrolyte levels are within normal limits, with a potassium level of 3.2 mEq/L.

The patient's medical history is significant for chronic atrial fibrillation, chronic systolic heart failure with an ejection fraction of 20%, and recurrent VT. He has undergone a VT ablation procedure twice and has been treated with amiodarone and lidocaine.

The patient's current medications include amiodarone, verapamil, diltiazem, metoprolol, aspirin, and statin. He is also receiving prophylactic heparin and colace/senna.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Ventricular tachycardia: The patient's history of recurrent VT and his current pacemaker rhythm make it likely that he will continue to experience VT episodes.
2. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and his current pacemaker rhythm make it likely that he will experience other cardiac arrhythmias, such as atrial flutter or ventricular fibrillation.
3. Heart failure: The patient's history of chronic systolic heart failure and his current pacemaker rhythm make it likely that he will experience heart failure exacerbations.
4. Infection: The patient's current antibiotics and prophylactic heparin make it likely that he will experience an infection, such as pneumonia or urinary tract infection.
5. Bleeding: The patient's current prophylactic heparin and colace/senna make it likely that he will experience bleeding, such as gastrointestinal bleeding or intracranial bleeding.
6. Sedation: The patient's current sedation with propofol and his history of altered mental status make it likely that he will experience sedation-related complications, such as respiratory depression or hypotension.
7. Anxiety: The patient's current anxiety and his history of anxiety make it likely that he will experience anxiety-related complications, such as panic attacks or agitation.

Overall, the patient's condition is stable, but he is at risk for various medical complications. Close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and treat these complications.

The patient's assessment and plan include ICU care, nutrition, glycemic control, and prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcer, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient's code status is full code, and the disposition is to continue ICU care.

5. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and the risk of renal failure is increased.
6. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits, but the risk of electrolyte imbalance is always present in critically ill patients.
7. Wound complications: The patient's skin examination is normal, but the risk of wound complications is always present in patients with critical illness.

In summary, the patient is a critically ill individual with a paced rhythm, intubated, and sedated. The patient's vital signs are stable, and the patient is receiving respiratory support. The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 11.5 K/uL, a hemoglobin level of 12.2 g/dL, and a platelet count of 199 K/uL. The patient's assessment and plan include ICU care, nutrition, glycemic control, and prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP. The patient's code status is full code, and the disposition is to continue ICU care.

Summary:

The patient is a 78.7 kg individual who was admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of VT. They have been paced at 60 beats per minute and have not experienced any episodes of VT overnight. The patient's family has expressed a desire to change the battery and generator at some point. The patient has a history of allergies to morphine, mirtazapine, and ambien, and has received antibiotics via infusion. They are currently receiving medications including famotidine, heparin sodium, and other ICU medications.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.9°C, heart rate of 60 beats per minute, blood pressure of 96/50 mmHg, respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 94%. They are receiving respiratory support via a ventilator in CPAP/PSV mode, with a Vt of 460 mL, PS of 5 cmH2O, and FiO2 of 50%.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 11.5, hemoglobin of 12.2 g/dL, and platelet count of 199 K/uL. Their blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine levels are elevated, and their potassium and magnesium levels are within normal limits. The patient's glucose level is 123 mg/dL, and their lactate level is 28 mmol/L.

The patient's physical examination is significant for a stable cardiovascular status, with a normal heart rhythm and blood pressure. They are receiving prophylactic antibiotics and stress ulcer prophylaxis.

Potential medical complications:

1. Ventricular tachycardia: The patient's history of VT and current pacing at 60 beats per minute make them at risk for recurrent VT.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's respiratory support and potential for aspiration make them at risk for developing pneumonia.
3. Sepsis: The patient's elevated BUN and creatinine levels, as well as their potential for bacterial colonization, make them at risk for developing sepsis.
4. Deep vein thrombosis: The patient's use of heparin sodium for prophylaxis makes them at risk for developing DVT.
5. Stress ulcer: The patient's use of stress ulcer prophylaxis makes them at risk for developing stress ulcers.
6. VAP: The patient's use of respiratory support and potential for aspiration make them at risk for developing VAP.
7. Malnutrition: The patient's potential for malnutrition due to their ICU stay and lack of oral intake make them at risk for malnutrition.
8. Hypoglycemia: The patient's potential for hypoglycemia due to their diabetes and insulin therapy make them at risk for developing hypoglycemia.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 78.7 kg individual who has been admitted to the ICU for an unknown duration. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature range of 36.9-37.4°C, heart rate of 60-71 bpm, blood pressure of 96/50-126/69 mmHg, respiratory rate of 19-25 inspirations per minute, and oxygen saturation of 94%.

The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation with a CPAP/PSV mode, with a tidal volume of 460-491 mL, peak inspiratory pressure of 11 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50%. The patient's blood gases show a partial pressure of oxygen (pO2) of 28 mmHg, partial pressure of carbon dioxide (pCO2) of 28 mmHg, and pH of 7.3.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count (WBC) of 11.5-14.2 K/uL, hemoglobin (Hb) of 12.2-14.2 g/dL, and platelet count (Plt) of 17-199 K/uL. The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits, with the exception of a slightly elevated potassium level.

The patient is receiving several medications, including antibiotics, antacids, and sedatives. The patient's physical examination is limited due to the lack of assessment of peripheral vascular, skin, neurologic, and other systems.

Potential medical complications that can arise based on this information include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's oxygen saturation is 94%, which may indicate a risk of respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's WBC count is elevated, which may indicate an underlying infection.
3. Bleeding: The patient's platelet count is low, which may increase the risk of bleeding.
4. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's potassium level is slightly elevated, which may indicate an electrolyte imbalance.
5. Infection: The patient's antibiotic therapy may not be adequate, which may increase the risk of infection.
6. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation, which may increase the risk of VAP.
7. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient is receiving prophylactic heparin, which may not be adequate to prevent DVT.
8. Stress ulcer: The patient's sedative therapy may increase the risk of stress ulcer.

Further evaluation and monitoring are necessary to assess the patient's condition and prevent potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known firstname 20**] [**Known lastname **] is a 86 yo Russian speaking man with h/o CAD s/p MI and
   CABG in [**2136**], chronic AFib with V-pacing, chronic systolic CHF with EF
   20%, recently discharged from CCU with ICD firing, now returns with
   recurrent VT on PO amiodarone, now s/p VT ablation procedure x 2.
   .
   #. Rhythm - Pt with known VTach and s/p ICD firing, presented due to
   ICD firing and chest pain. Patient has stable VS and was in VT at
   120-130s. He was bolused with 450 mg of IV amiodarone in the ER and was
   on a gtt. He is currently DNR/DNI after undergoing a successful VT
   ablation for which his code status was changed to full code.  Code
   status reversed after procedure.  Was stable until he developed VT
   overnight on [**9-23**].  Was repaced into sinus rhythm and transferred back
   to CCU.  Again went into VT.  VT detect re-set to 115 from 140.
   Patient received multiple shocks and has been in sinus rhythm since
   2AM.  Lidocaine and amiodarone gtt were started but patient became
   agitated and lost IV access.  Lidocaine had not worked well in the past
   for patient.
   - LV pacing at 60 currently
   - RV pacing off.
   - now s/p ablation x 2 (most recently [**2147-9-25**])
   - Currently pt is paced and in sinus; intrinsic conduction.
   - Keep ICD on
   - family wants generator changed at some point
   - D/C amiodarone and started verapamil yesterday.
   - Add diltiazem IV if goes into Vtach
   .
   # Respiratory
 extubated, off sedation, off pressors.
   .
   #. Pump - No signs of CHF at this time. Pt with known chronic systolic
   heart failure with EF of 20%. We will continue his home medications:
   statin, ASA, and metoprolol.
   -No signs of decompensation at the moment.  Monitor UOP since pt
   received a lot of fluids during his ablation.
   .
   # Leukocytosis- WBC up to 14.2 this AM (~9 yesterday).  Increased stool
   overnight and abdominal tenderness to exam this morning.  Possible
   C.diff
   - Stool sent for C.diff toxin
   - Patient started on Flagyl 500mg PO TID
   .
   #. CAD - Pt with known CAD s/p CABG. Chest pain free, other than his VT
   and shocks.  ASA, statin, BB were continued as above.  ACEI held as
   above, due to hypotension. Enzymes suggest mild cardiac injury after
   shock, but most likely he is not having ACS.
   .
   #. OA - pain was well controlled on Tylenol.  No opiates given altered
   mental status history with opioid administration
   .
   #. Anxiety - Discontinued ativan home-dose. Consider low dose mood
   stabilizer at night, if agitation continues.
   -Received Olanzapine sublingual 2.5mg with good response four nights
   ago
   -Pt altered mental status and anxiety seem to be improving.  Currently
   on propofol while intubated.
   - If agitated, consider zydis again vs. haldol 1 mg
   FEN:
   - Hypokalemic to 3.2 this AM.
   - Will replete with 80mEq IV K+.
   - Follow lytes
   .
   #. Code - patient is DNR/DNI.  Not to be externally shocked. Leave ICD
   on
   .
   #. Prophy
 DVT: heparin SQ; No need for PPI; Colace/Senna.
   .
   #. Contact - Next of [**Doctor First Name **]: [**Last Name (LF) **],[**First Name3 (LF) **], Relationship: DAUGHTER, Phone:
   [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9232**] (home) and [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9287**] (cell).
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   20 Gauge - [**2147-9-25**] 03:03 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: heparin SQ
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:  off ventilator
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition: CCU for now

   Attending
s Note.
   Reviewed overnight course,
   Quite stable.Examined Pt.

s note.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following information is summarized:

* The patient is an 86-year-old man with a history of CAD, s/p MI and CABG, chronic AFib with V-pacing, and chronic systolic CHF with EF 20%.
* The patient was recently discharged from CCU with ICD firing, and returned with recurrent VT on PO amiodarone, which led to VT ablation procedure x 2.
* The patient is currently extubated, off sedation, and off pressors. LV pacing is at 60, and RV pacing is off.
* The patient has a history of C. diff, and stool was sent for C. diff toxin. The patient is currently on Flagyl 500mg PO TID.
* The patient has leukocytosis, with WBC up to 14.2 this AM. Abdominal tenderness is present, and possible C. diff is suspected.
* The patient has chronic systolic heart failure with EF 20%, and is on home medications: statin, ASA, and metoprolol.
* The patient has known CAD s/p CABG, and chest pain is controlled with ASA, statin, and BB.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* C. diff infection, which can lead to severe diarrhea, abdominal pain, and potentially life-threatening complications.
* Leukocytosis, which can indicate an underlying infection or inflammation, and may require further evaluation and treatment.
* Chronic systolic heart failure, which can lead to cardiac decompensation, heart failure exacerbation, and potentially life-threatening complications.
* CAD, which can lead to recurrent myocardial infarction, heart failure, and potentially life-threatening complications.
* VT, which can lead to cardiac arrest, shock, and potentially life-threatening complications.
* ICD firing, which can lead to cardiac arrest, shock, and potentially life-threatening complications.

Based on the patient's current condition and medical history, close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and treat potential complications.

   Mr. [**Known firstname 20**] [**Known lastname **] is a 86 yo Russian speaking man with h/o CAD s/p MI and
   CABG in [**2136**], chronic AFib with V-pacing, chronic systolic CHF with EF
   20%, recently discharged from CCU with ICD firing, now returns with
   recurrent VT on PO amiodarone, now s/p VT ablation procedure x 2.
   .
   #. Rhythm - Pt with known VTach and s/p ICD firing, presented due to
   ICD firing and chest pain. Patient has stable VS and was in VT at
   120-130s. He was bolused with 450 mg of IV amiodarone in the ER and was
   on a gtt. He is currently DNR/DNI after undergoing a successful VT
   ablation for which his code status was changed to full code.  Code
   status reversed after procedure.  Was stable until he developed VT
   overnight on [**9-23**].  Was repaced into sinus rhythm and transferred back
   to CCU.  Again went into VT.  VT detect re-set to 115 from 140.
   Patient received multiple shocks and has been in sinus rhythm since
   2AM.  Lidocaine and amiodarone gtt were started but patient became
   agitated and lost IV access.  Lidocaine had not worked well in the past
   for patient.
   - LV pacing at 60 currently
   - RV pacing off.
   - now s/p ablation x 2 (most recently [**2147-9-25**])
   - Currently pt is paced and in sinus; intrinsic conduction.
   - Keep ICD on
   - family wants generator changed at some point
   - D/C amiodarone and started verapamil yesterday.
   - Add diltiazem IV if goes into Vtach
   .
   # Respiratory
 extubated, off sedation, off pressors.
   .
   #. Pump - No signs of CHF at this time. Pt with known chronic systolic
   heart failure with EF of 20%. We will continue his home medications:
   statin, ASA, and metoprolol.
   -No signs of decompensation at the moment.  Monitor UOP since pt
   received a lot of fluids during his ablation.
   .
   #. CAD - Pt with known CAD s/p CABG. Chest pain free, other than his VT
   and shocks.  ASA, statin, BB were continued as above.  ACEI held as
   above, due to hypotension. Enzymes suggest mild cardiac injury after
   shock, but most likely he is not having ACS.
   .
   #. OA - pain was well controlled on Tylenol.  No opiates given altered
   mental status history with opioid administration
   .
   #. Anxiety - Discontinued ativan home-dose. Consider low dose mood
   stabilizer at night, if agitation continues.
   -Received Olanzapine sublingual 2.5mg with good response four nights
   ago
   -Pt altered mental status and anxiety seem to be improving.  Currently
   on propofol while intubated.
   - If agitated, consider zydis again vs. haldol 1 mg
   FEN:
   - Hypokalemic to 3.2 this AM.
   - Will replete with 40mEq IV K+.
   - Follow lytes
   .
   #. Code - patient is DNR/DNI.  Not to be externally shocked. Leave ICD
   on
   .
   #. Prophy
 DVT: heparin SQ; No need for PPI; Colace/Senna.
   .

Summary:

The patient is an 86-year-old man who was admitted to the ICU due to recurrent ventricular tachycardia (VT) and ICD firing. He has a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) and chronic systolic heart failure (CHF) with an ejection fraction (EF) of 20%. He underwent a successful VT ablation procedure, but continues to experience VT episodes. The patient is currently paced at 60 beats per minute and is in sinus rhythm. He is extubated and off sedation, but still requires oxygen therapy. His electrolyte levels are within normal limits, except for hypokalemia, which is being treated with IV potassium repletion. The patient's code status is DNR/DNI, and he is not to be externally shocked.

Potential medical complications:

1. Recurrence of VT: The patient's history of recurrent VT and ICD firing suggests that he may continue to experience VT episodes, which could lead to further complications, such as cardiac arrest or stroke.
2. Cardiac decompensation: The patient's chronic systolic heart failure and EF of 20% make him prone to cardiac decompensation, which could be exacerbated by further VT episodes or other cardiac conditions.
3. Hypokalemia: The patient's hypokalemia could lead to cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, and other electrolyte imbalances.
4. Infection: The patient's prolonged hospitalization and use of central lines and other invasive devices increase his risk of developing infections, such as central line-associated bloodstream infections (CLABSIs) or ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
5. Medication side effects: The patient's use of various medications, including amiodarone, verapamil, and diltiazem, could lead to side effects, such as nausea, vomiting, and altered mental status.
6. Family conflicts: The patient's family members have expressed concerns about his care, including their desire to change the generator of his ICD. This could lead to conflicts and challenges in the patient's care.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 86-year-old Russian-speaking man with a history of CAD, s/p MI and CABG, chronic AFib with V-pacing, and chronic systolic CHF with EF 20%. He has recently been discharged from the CCU with an ICD firing and chest pain, and has undergone VT ablation.

The patient is currently experiencing diffuse abdominal pain, tenderness, and guarding, with no signs of rebound or peritoneal signs. The abdominal pain is likely related to the patient's history of CAD, chronic systolic CHF, and recent ICD firing.

The patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis with a left shift, and a differential diagnosis of C. Diff, UTI, diverticulitis, ischemic bowel disease, and pneumonia is considered. The patient's WBC count is elevated, with a differential count showing a left shift, which is consistent with an inflammatory response.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.8°C, a heart rate of 60 beats per minute, and a blood pressure of 95/47 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 90%.

The patient's physical examination shows a soft and non-distended abdomen, with no signs of rebound or peritoneal signs. His skin is intact, with no signs of stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas.

The patient's plan includes:

1. NPO
2. CT abdomen/pelvis to evaluate for potential causes of abdominal pain
3. Empiric treatment for C. Diff with flagyl 500 mg IV q8h and PO vancomycin
4. IV cipro to cover for potential diverticulitis
5. Trend lactates
6. Foley pulled, condom catheter in place, repeat UA, and f/u urine culture to rule out UTI
7. F/u blood cultures
8. F/u CXR to rule out aspiration, pneumonia
9. Start mIVF NS at 100 cc/hr
10. Hold lasix and ACEi
11. Repeat urine cx

The patient's code status is DNR/DNI, and he is not to be externally shocked. His ICD is to be left on.

In summary, the patient is an 86-year-old man with a history of CAD, chronic systolic CHF, and recent ICD firing, who is experiencing diffuse abdominal pain, tenderness, and guarding. The patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis with a left shift, and a differential diagnosis of C. Diff, UTI, diverticulitis, ischemic bowel disease, and pneumonia is considered. The patient's plan includes empiric treatment for C. Diff, IV cipro to cover for potential diverticulitis, and f/u blood cultures, urine cx, and CXR to rule out UTI and pneumonia.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 86-year-old Russian-speaking man with a history of coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction, and coronary artery bypass grafting. He has chronic atrial fibrillation with ventricular pacing, chronic systolic heart failure with an ejection fraction of 20%, and recently underwent a ventricular tachycardia (VT) ablation procedure.

The patient is currently in the ICU due to recurrent VT, which led to ICD firing and chest pain. He was bolused with IV amiodarone and was on a drip, but became agitated and lost IV access. He received multiple shocks and has been in sinus rhythm since 2 AM.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: T 37.7°C, HR 60 bpm, BP 95/47 mmHg, RR 24 inspirations per minute, SpO2 90%
* Respiratory support: Off sedation, off pressors, and extubated
* Cardiovascular: LV pacing at 60 bpm, RV pacing off, and ICD on
* Abdominal: Diffuse abdominal pain and tenderness, but abdomen is soft and without signs of rebound or guarding
* Hemodynamic monitoring: Hemodynamic monitoring is stable, with a mean arterial pressure of 95 mmHg
* Fluid balance: The patient has received a total of 2,630 mL of fluids, with an output of 1,320 mL
* Lab results: WBC 14.2 K/uL, Hct 37.7%, Plt 199, Cr 1.1 mg/dL, Glucose 123 mg/dL

Potential medical complications that can arise based on the patient's current condition include:

* Cardiac complications:
	+ Recurrent VT
	+ Heart failure decompensation
	+ Cardiac tamponade
* Abdominal complications:
	+ Intestinal obstruction
	+ Perforation
	+ Infection (e.g., C. difficile)
* Respiratory complications:
	+ Pneumonia
	+ Respiratory failure
	+ Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)
* Hemodynamic complications:
	+ Hypotension
	+ Hypertension
	+ Cardiac arrest

The patient's code status is DNR/DNI, and he is not to be externally shocked. His ICD should be left on, and his family has requested that the generator be changed at some point. The patient's abdominal pain is being managed with lactate testing, NPO status, and consideration of a CT abdomen/pelvis if the clinical exam worsens.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 70-inch tall male who weighs 78.7 kg. He has been in the ICU for several days and has been experiencing abdominal pain, which is sharp, constant, and diffuse. He has not had a bowel movement in 5 days and has been unable to pass stool despite trying twice today.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.7°C, heart rate of 60 bpm, and blood pressure of 95/47 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 90%. He is receiving mechanical ventilation and has a heart rhythm of atrioventricular paced.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and creatinine levels, as well as low platelet count. His electrolyte levels are within normal limits, except for a slightly low potassium level.

The patient's abdominal pain is likely related to constipation, which is a common complication of mechanical ventilation. The redundant bowel loops on the abdominal X-ray are also consistent with constipation.

The patient's delirium and confusion are likely related to his underlying medical conditions, including chronic heart failure and chronic kidney disease. His impaired physical mobility is also a common complication of mechanical ventilation.

The patient's impaired skin integrity is likely related to his prolonged bedrest and immobility. His heart failure is a chronic condition, and his ventricular tachycardia is likely related to his underlying heart disease.

The potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

1. Bowel perforation or obstruction due to constipation
2. Sepsis or septic shock due to constipation or other underlying infections
3. Worsening of heart failure or cardiac arrest due to tachycardia
4. Development of pressure ulcers or skin breakdown due to impaired skin integrity
5. Respiratory failure or worsening of respiratory distress due to mechanical ventilation
6. Increased risk of bleeding due to low platelet count
7. Electrolyte imbalances or acid-base disturbances due to chronic kidney disease

Based on the patient's condition, the following plan of care is recommended:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation and monitor the patient's respiratory status closely.
2. Administer lactate-free IV fluids to help manage constipation.
3. Consider ordering a rectal examination and digital rectal exam to assess the patient's bowel movement.
4. Monitor the patient's heart rate and rhythm closely and consider ordering a 12-lead electrocardiogram to assess for any changes.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's skin integrity and take measures to prevent pressure ulcers.
6. Consider ordering a stress test or echocardiogram to assess the patient's cardiac function.
7. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust his medications as necessary to prevent electrolyte imbalances.

The patient's code status is DNR/DNI, and his disposition is unclear at this time. Further discussion with the patient's family and healthcare team is necessary to determine the best course of action for the patient's care.

Summary:

The patient is a 70-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of diffuse abdominal pain, constipation, and recent diarrhea. He has been unable to pass stool for 5 days and has reported trying to have a bowel movement twice today without success. The patient's abdominal pain is sharp, constant, and diffuse, with no rebound tenderness or guarding on examination. Radiological studies, including an abdominal x-ray, have revealed redundant bowel loops in the right upper quadrant, but no evidence of obstruction or perforation.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.7°C, heart rate of 60 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 95/47 mmHg. He is receiving heparin prophylaxis and has a history of chronic heart failure and ventricular tachycardia.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, lactate level, and creatinine level, as well as low hemoglobin and platelet count. His electrolyte levels are within normal limits, except for a slightly low potassium level.

Potential medical complications:

1. Bowel obstruction or perforation: The patient's symptoms of constipation, diarrhea, and abdominal pain may be indicative of a bowel obstruction or perforation, which could lead to complications such as sepsis, peritonitis, or bowel necrosis.
2. Sepsis: The patient's elevated lactate level and white blood cell count may indicate the presence of sepsis, which could lead to multi-organ dysfunction and death.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of chronic heart failure and ventricular tachycardia may increase his risk of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, cardiogenic shock, or cardiac arrest.
4. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's constipation and recent diarrhea may increase his risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, which could lead to hypovolemic shock and other complications.
5. Dehydration: The patient's constipation and diarrhea may lead to dehydration, which could exacerbate his existing medical conditions and increase his risk of complications.
6. Respiratory failure: The patient's chronic heart failure and potential respiratory compromise may increase his risk of respiratory failure, which could require mechanical ventilation.

Given the patient's symptoms and laboratory results, it is essential to continue monitoring his condition closely and addressing any potential complications promptly to prevent further deterioration.

   Mr. [**Known firstname 20**] [**Known lastname **] is a 86 yo Russian speaking man with h/o CAD s/p MI and
   CABG in [**2136**], chronic AFib with V-pacing, chronic systolic CHF with EF
   20%, recently discharged from CCU with ICD firing, now returns with
   recurrent VT on PO amiodarone, now s/p VT ablation procedure x 2 and
   with new onset leukocytosis and abdominal pain.
   .
   #. Rhythm - Pt with known VTach, presented due to ICD firing and chest
   pain, s/p VT ablation [**2147-9-25**], patient with improved rhythm, but still
   has occasional runs of NSVT at 120-130s. O/n, occasional episodes of
   Vtach which converted, without shocks or other intervention.
   - Off amio, off lido, continue CCB for triggered ecotopy.
   - LV pacing at 60 currently
   - RV pacing off.
   - Keep ICD on
   - Family wants generator changed at some point
   - Add diltiazem IV if goes into Vtach
   .
   #Leukocytosis with left shift, differential diagnosis includes C. Diff
   (possible despite negative c. diff toxin assay x 1, given abdominal
   pain, diarrhea and rapidly rising WBC and test has a sensitivity of
   60-90%. ), UTI (possible given cloudy urine, 9 WBCs and a few bacterial
   cells seen on UA with micro, diverticulitis, given age of patient and
   location of pain, possible but less likely, ischemic bowel disease,
   unlikely given normal lactate, pneumonia, possible as s/p intubation
   -F/u c. diff stool assay x 2 to rule out C. Diff
   -Consider addition of empiric flagyl 500 mg IV q8
   -Foley pulled, condom catheter in place, repeat UA, F/u urine culture
   to rule out UTI, begin empiric cipro
   - F/u blood cultures
   -F/u CXR to rule out aspiration, pneumonia
   .
   # Abdominal pain
 pt with diffuse abdominal pain/tenderness, but
   abdomen soft and without signs of rebound/guarding.  AXR ordered and no
   signs of obstruction or perforation; redundant bowel loops noted in RUQ
   with size 4 cm (unclear if small bowel or colon, as per wet read with
   radiology). Differential diagnosis includes C. Diff, ischemic disease,
   unlikely given negative lactate, diverticulitis, possible given
   patient
s age and location of pain, pancreatitis, unlikely given normal
   lipase, hepato-biliary disease, unlikely given normal LFTs, and
   decreasing bili, pyelonephritis, unlikely given afebrile and negative
   nitrites on UA, UTI causing suprapubic pain, possible given hazy urine
   and 9 WBCs on micro.
   - NPO
   - consider CT abdomen/pelvis if clinical exam worsens
   -Consider starting flagyl 500 mg IV q8h to empiricially treat for C.
   Diff
   .
   #Hyponatremia- Na this AM 126, yesterday was 135. Likely false result
   given patient did not demonstrate thirst yesterday, and did not have an
   excessive free water intake. The patient has been putting out an
   appropriate amount of urine, making SIADH or other cerebral salt
   wasting unlikely.
   -F/u repeat Na, f/u urine lytes
   .
   # Respiratory
 extubated, off sedation, off pressors and maintaining
   adequate O2 sat and pressure
   .
   #. Pump - No signs of CHF at this time. Pt with known chronic systolic
   heart failure with EF of 20%. We will continue his home medications:
   statin, ASA, and metoprolol.
   -No signs of decompensation at the moment.  Monitor UOP since pt
   received a lot of fluids during his ablation.
   .
   #. CAD - Pt with known CAD s/p CABG. Chest pain free, other than his VT
   and shocks.  ASA, statin, BB were continued as above.  ACEI held as
   above, due to hypotension. Enzymes suggested  mild cardiac injury on
   presentation, resolved, likely did not have ACS.
   .
   #. OA - pain was well controlled on Tylenol.  No opiates given altered
   mental status history with opioid administration
   .
   #. Anxiety - Discontinued ativan home-dose. Consider low dose mood
   stabilizer at night, if agitation continues.
   -Pt altered mental status and anxiety seem to be improving.
   - If agitated, consider zydis  vs. haldol 1 mg
   .
   FEN:
   - Currently NPO
   -Continue to follow lytes and replete as necessary
   .
   #. Code - patient is DNR/DNI.  Not to be externally shocked. Leave ICD
   on
   .
   #. Prophy
 DVT: heparin SQ; No need for PPI; Colace/Senna.
   .
   #. Contact - Next of [**Doctor First Name **]: [**Last Name (LF) **],[**First Name3 (LF) **], Relationship: DAUGHTER, Phone:

Based on the patient's daily progress note, I summarize the following information:

The patient is an 86-year-old Russian-speaking man with a history of CAD, s/p MI and CABG, chronic AFib with V-pacing, chronic systolic CHF with EF 20%, and recent discharge from CCU with ICD firing. He returns with recurrent VT on PO amiodarone, now s/p VT ablation procedure x 2, and new onset leukocytosis and abdominal pain.

The patient's abdominal pain is diffuse, constant, and sharp, with no rebound or guarding. Abdominal tenderness is present, and AXR shows no signs of obstruction or perforation, but redundant bowel loops are noted in the RUQ. The differential diagnosis includes C. Diff, ischemic disease, diverticulitis, pancreatitis, and pyelonephritis.

The patient's leukocytosis is significant, with a left shift, and the differential diagnosis includes C. Diff, UTI, and other possibilities. The patient's abdominal pain and leukocytosis are likely related, and further evaluation is needed to determine the cause.

The patient's cardiac status is stable, with a paced rhythm and normal S1 and S2. He has a history of chronic systolic CHF with EF 20% and is on home medications, including statin, ASA, and metoprolol.

The patient's respiratory status is stable, with adequate O2 saturation and pressure. He is extubated and off sedation and pressors.

The patient's electrolyte status is abnormal, with hyponatremia, which is likely a false result given the patient's adequate urine output and lack of thirst.

The patient's medication list includes heparin, lactate, and other medications, and he is currently NPO.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. C. Diff colitis: The patient's abdominal pain, diarrhea, and leukocytosis are concerning for C. Diff colitis. Further evaluation, including stool assays and empiric treatment, is needed.
2. UTI: The patient's cloudy urine, WBCs, and bacterial cells on UA are concerning for UTI. Further evaluation, including urine cultures and empiric treatment, is needed.
3. Ischemic bowel disease: The patient's abdominal pain and leukocytosis are concerning for ischemic bowel disease. Further evaluation, including imaging studies and empiric treatment, is needed.
4. Pneumonia: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but pneumonia is still a possibility given his recent intubation and hospitalization.
5. Heart failure: The patient's cardiac status is stable, but heart failure is still a possibility given his chronic systolic CHF and recent hospitalization.

Based on the patient's condition, I recommend the following:

1. Continue empiric treatment for C. Diff and UTI.
2. Further evaluation, including imaging studies and empiric treatment, to rule out ischemic bowel disease.
3. Continue monitoring the patient's cardiac status and respiratory status.
4. Continue to manage the patient's electrolyte status and hydration.
5. Consider starting flagyl 500 mg IV q8h to empirically treat for C. Diff.
6. Consider adding empiric cipro to treat for UTI.
7. Continue to follow the patient's lab results and adjust treatment accordingly.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the patient's condition and potential medical complications:

**Patient's Condition:**

The patient is an 86-year-old Russian-speaking man with a history of CAD, s/p MI and CABG, chronic AFib with V-pacing, chronic systolic CHF with EF 20%, and recently discharged from CCU with ICD firing. He is currently in the ICU with abdominal pain, diarrhea, and leukocytosis.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Clostridioides difficile (C. Diff) Infection**: The patient's abdominal pain, diarrhea, and leukocytosis are concerning for C. Diff infection, which is a possible diagnosis despite a negative C. Diff toxin assay. Further stool assays are planned to rule out C. Diff.
2. **Urinary Tract Infection (UTI)**: The patient's cloudy urine, 9 WBCs, and a few bacterial cells seen on UA with micro are concerning for UTI. A Foley catheter has been removed, and a condom catheter is in place. A urine culture is planned to rule out UTI.
3. **Ischemic Bowel Disease**: The patient's abdominal pain and tenderness could be related to ischemic bowel disease, although the lactate level is normal.
4. **Diverticulitis**: The patient's age and location of pain suggest diverticulitis as a possible diagnosis.
5. **Pyelonephritis**: The patient's hazy urine and 9 WBCs on micro could be related to pyelonephritis, although the patient is afebrile and the UA is negative for nitrites.
6. **Hepato-biliary Disease**: The patient's abdominal pain and tenderness could be related to hepato-biliary disease, although the LFTs are normal and the bili level is decreasing.
7. **Pancreatitis**: The patient's abdominal pain and tenderness could be related to pancreatitis, although the lipase level is normal.
8. **Hyponatremia**: The patient's sodium level is low, which could be related to SIADH or other cerebral salt wasting. Further evaluation is planned.
9. **Ventricular Tachycardia**: The patient's ICD has fired, and he has had occasional episodes of VTach. The rhythm is currently controlled with CCB.
10. **Heart Failure**: The patient has chronic systolic CHF with EF 20%, and his condition needs to be closely monitored for signs of decompensation.

**Plan:**

1. NPO status to rule out C. Diff.
2. Consider CT abdomen/pelvis if clinical exam worsens.
3. Consider starting flagyl 500 mg IV q8h to empirically treat for C. Diff.
4. F/u repeat Na and urine lytes.
5. Monitor UOP since the patient received a lot of fluids during his ablation.
6. Continue home medications for CAD, CHF, and statin.
7. Consider low-dose mood stabilizer at night if agitation continues.
8. F/u with next of kin, daughter, at [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9232**] (home) and [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9287**] (cell).

   Patient received multiple shocks and has been in sinus rhythm since

   for patient.
   - LV pacing at 70 currently
   - RV pacing off.

   - Currently pt is paced and in sinus; intrinsic conduction.

 extubated, off sedation, off pressors.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 86-year-old Russian-speaking man with a history of CAD, s/p MI and CABG, chronic AFib with V-pacing, chronic systolic CHF with EF 20%, and recent discharge from CCU with ICD firing. He was readmitted due to recurrent VT on PO amiodarone, which led to ICD firing and chest pain.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: T 36.4°C, HR 72 bpm, BP 125/50 mmHg, RR 17 inspirations per minute, SpO2 93%
* Respiratory support: Extubated, off sedation, and off pressors
* Cardiovascular: Paced and in sinus rhythm, with LV pacing at 70 and RV pacing off
* Leukocytosis: WBC count increased to 20.7 this afternoon, with possible C. diff infection
* Abdominal pain: Mildly tender to palpation, with possible colitis
* Confusion: Increased confusion throughout the day, with yelling in Russian and agitation
* Medications: Empiric antibiotics (Flagyl, Cipro, and Vanc) for possible C. diff infection, and antipsychotics (Zyprexa and Lorazepam) for agitation

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's leukocytosis and abdominal pain suggest possible infection, which can lead to sepsis if left untreated.
2. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of VT and ICD firing increases the risk of recurrent arrhythmias, which can be life-threatening.
3. Heart failure: The patient's chronic systolic CHF with EF 20% increases the risk of decompensation, particularly with fluid overload.
4. C. difficile infection: The patient's increased stool output and abdominal pain suggest possible C. diff infection, which can lead to severe diarrhea, colitis, and sepsis.
5. Agitation and delirium: The patient's increased confusion and agitation can lead to delirium, which can increase the risk of falls, respiratory failure, and cardiac arrhythmias.

Given the patient's complex medical condition and potential complications, it is essential to continue monitoring his vital signs, laboratory results, and medication regimen closely.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 86-year-old Russian-speaking man with a history of coronary artery disease, recent myocardial infarction, and chronic systolic heart failure with an ejection fraction of 20%. He has undergone a ventricular tachycardia (VT) ablation procedure twice and is currently being treated in the intensive care unit (ICU) for recurrent VT.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: blood pressure (BP) 125/50 mmHg, heart rate (HR) 72 bpm, respiratory rate (RR) 17 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation (SpO2) 93%.
* Laboratory results: white blood cell count (WBC) 20.7 K/uL, hemoglobin (Hb) 10.8 g/dL, platelet count (Plt) 190 K/uL, creatinine (Cr) 1.1 mg/dL, and blood urea nitrogen (BUN) 27 mg/dL.
* Radiology results: CT abdomen with contrast shows segmental inflammation of the sigmoid colon, suggestive of colitis.
* Medications: the patient is receiving various medications, including antibiotics (Flagyl, Cipro, and Vanc), anticonvulsants (Lorazepam), and antihypertensives (verapamil).

The patient's clinical condition is concerning due to the following reasons:

* Recurrent VT, which may indicate a high risk of cardiac arrhythmias and potentially life-threatening events.
* Colitis, which may be related to antibiotic use or underlying gastrointestinal disease.
* Leukocytosis, which may indicate an underlying infection or inflammation.
* Hypotension, which may be related to fluid overload, cardiac dysfunction, or medication side effects.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Cardiac arrhythmias, such as ventricular fibrillation or atrial fibrillation, which may require urgent intervention.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation due to colitis.
* Infection, such as sepsis, which may require broad-spectrum antibiotics and close monitoring.
* Fluid overload, which may require diuretic therapy and close monitoring of fluid balance.
* Hypotension, which may require vasopressor therapy and close monitoring of blood pressure.

Based on the patient's condition and potential complications, it is recommended to:

* Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and adjust medications as necessary to prevent arrhythmias.
* Manage the patient's colitis with antibiotics and close monitoring of gastrointestinal symptoms.
* Replete electrolytes as needed to prevent complications related to electrolyte imbalances.
* Monitor the patient's fluid balance and adjust diuretic therapy as necessary to prevent fluid overload.
* Consider consulting with a cardiologist or gastroenterologist to further evaluate the patient's condition and develop a comprehensive treatment plan.

   Mr. [**Known firstname 20**] [**Known lastname **] is a 86 yo Russian speaking man with h/o CAD s/p MI and
   CABG in [**2136**], chronic AFib with V-pacing, chronic systolic CHF with EF
   20%, recently discharged from CCU with ICD firing, now returns with
   recurrent VT on PO amiodarone, now s/p VT ablation procedure x 2.
   .
   #. Rhythm - Pt with known VTach and s/p ICD firing, presented due to
   ICD firing and chest pain. Patient has stable VS and was in VT at
   120-130s. He was bolused with 450 mg of IV amiodarone in the ER and was
   on a gtt. He is currently DNR/DNI after undergoing a successful VT
   ablation for which his code status was changed to full code.  Code
   status reversed after procedure.  Was stable until he developed VT
   overnight on [**9-23**].  Was repaced into sinus rhythm and transferred back
   to CCU.  Again went into VT.  VT detect re-set to 115 from 140.
   Patient received multiple shocks and has been in sinus rhythm since
   2AM.  Lidocaine and amiodarone gtt were started but patient became
   agitated and lost IV access.  Lidocaine had not worked well in the past
   for patient.
   - LV pacing at 70 currently
   - RV pacing off.
   - now s/p ablation x 2 (most recently [**2147-9-25**])
   - Currently pt is paced and in sinus; intrinsic conduction.
   - Keep ICD on
   - family wants generator changed at some point
   - On verapamil.
   - Add diltiazem IV if goes into Vtach
   .
   # Respiratory
 extubated, off sedation, off pressors.
   .
   #. Pump - No signs of CHF at this time. Pt with known chronic systolic
   heart failure with EF of 20%. We will continue his home medications:
   statin, ASA, and metoprolol.
   -No signs of decompensation at the moment.  Monitor UOP since pt
   received a lot of fluids during his ablation.
   -Gentle hydration with D5-NS at 50ml/hr today given low BP.  Will
   monitor for signs of fluid overload
   .
   # Leukocytosis- WBC down today (20.7 from 24).  No stool since
   yesterday AM.  Abdominal tenderness improved.  CT abd showed sigmoid
   colitis.  Unclear etiology.  Have not ruled out C.diff but it is
   unlikely given improving symptoms and decreasing white count.
   -Continue IV cipro
   - Will stop Flagyl and vanc this AM.
   - Urine sensitivities pending- will tailor abx therapy accordingly
   .
   #. CAD - Pt with known CAD s/p CABG. Chest pain free, other than his VT
   and shocks.  ASA, statin, BB were continued as above.  ACEI held as
   above, due to hypotension. Enzymes suggest mild cardiac injury after
   shock, but most likely he is not having ACS.
   .
   #. OA - pain was well controlled on Tylenol.  No opiates given altered
   mental status history with opioid administration
   .
   #. Anxiety - Discontinued ativan home-dose. Consider low dose mood
   stabilizer at night, if agitation continues.
   -Received Olanzapine sublingual 2.5mg with good response four nights
   ago
   -Pt altered mental status and anxiety seem to be improving.  Currently
   on propofol while intubated.
   -If agitated, consider zydis again vs. haldol 1 mg
   FEN:   Hyponatremic recently.  Lytes this AM show Na+ of 139 (after
   hydration yesterday).
   -continue to monitor lytes
   -Replete lytes as needed
   .
   #. Code - patient is DNR/DNI.  Not to be externally shocked. Leave ICD
   on
   .
   #. Prophy
 DVT: heparin SQ; No need for PPI; Colace/Senna.
